examples.en: After a generation, that Italian restaurant has closed.
examples.ja: あのイタリアンレストランは一代でクローズしてしまった。

examples.en: The owner has made this hotel the best hotel in Japan in one generation.
examples.ja: オーナーは一代でこのホテルを日本一のホテルにしました。

examples.en: In one generation, my father turned a small convenience store into a big department store.
examples.ja: 父は一代で小さいコンビニエンスストアを大きなデパートにしたんです。

meaning_mnemonic: This word has the kanji for <kanji>one</kanji> and <kanji>period</kanji>. You only have one period to live in so this is the only <vocabulary>lifetime</vocabulary> you get. Unless you're reborn, but that will probably be in the next age, not this one. So one lifetime for you!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: The mountain you can see in the northwest is Mt. Fuji.
examples.ja: 北西に見える山が、ふじ山です。

examples.en: There is a town called Seaside northwest of Portland.
examples.ja: ポートランドの北西に、シーサイドという町があります。

examples.en: There is a supermarket in the northwest corner.
examples.ja: 北西の角にスーパーが一つあります。

meaning_mnemonic: This word is so simple. <kanji>North</kanji> + <kanji>west</kanji> = <vocabulary>northwest</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You've seen these readings in words like 東北 and 西洋, so if you can remember this is on'yomi, you'll be good to go here.

examples.en: Please go straight to the entrance.
examples.ja: 入り口に直行して下さい。

examples.en: This is a direct flight to New York.
examples.ja: これは、ニューヨーク直行のフライトですよ。

examples.en: I went straight to the toilet afterwards.
examples.ja: 後でトイレに直行した。

meaning_mnemonic:
You proceed <kanji>straight</kanji> ahead to <kanji>go</kanji> somewhere because you're <vocabulary>going directly</vocabulary> there. You're making a <vocabulary>nonstop</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>direct</vocabulary> trip — no pitstops or detours.

直行 is commonly seen in transportation contexts, especially when talking about flights. It's also often used in business settings to describe traveling directly to a destination without making any stops, like visiting a client’s office straight from your home.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word and uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. The ちょく of 直 is shortened with a small っ, though, so make sure to take note of that.

examples.en: When will summer vacation start?
examples.ja: 夏休みはいつから始まりますか？

examples.en: Run! The concert is starting!
examples.ja: 走って！コンサートが始まっちゃうよ！

examples.en: Snack time begins at three o'clock.
examples.ja: 三時になると、おやつの時間が始まる。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means start, and this verb means to begin or to start. 始まる is the intransitive version, so it doesn't take a direct object. A war begins, for example, or the new school term starts. No direct object, right? Verbs ending in okurigana that rhyme with ある tend to be intransitive like this. You can remember this because if something is ある, it's just there, existing, not acting on anything else. That's why verbs that sound like it are often intransitive too!
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading.

Lucky for you, the kanji readings for transitive and intransitive verbs are almost always the same. Once you learn one, you know them both! This reading is the same as 始める.

examples.en: My mother is waiting for me at home.
examples.ja: お母さんが家で私を待っています。

examples.en: I'll be waiting at the airport.
examples.ja: 空港で待ってますね。

examples.en: Wait! I might have forgotten my wallet at home.
examples.ja: ちょっと待って！財布を家に忘れたかも。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>wait</kanji> so the verb version is <vocabulary>to wait</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: You need <vocabulary>to wait</vocabulary> for your <reading>ma</reading>ma (ま) all the time. You want to go out? You have to wait for mama to drive you. Want to eat dinner? You have to wait for mama to make you food. Hmm. Maybe all this waiting is really a you problem.

examples.en: I think they are just pretending to be intimate friends and they don't actually like each other.
examples.ja: あの二人、仲良しなふりをしているだけで、本当は仲が悪いと思うよ。

examples.en: The other day, I received an email from a close friend who lives in Japan.
examples.ja: 先日、日本に住んでいる仲良しの友人から、メールが来ました。

examples.en: Those kids are really good friends, aren't they?
examples.ja: あの子たち、ホントに仲良しだよね！

meaning_mnemonic:
When your <kanji>relationship</kanji> with someone is really <kanji>good</kanji>, you naturally become <vocabulary>good friend</vocabulary>s. You're always palling around together and acting <vocabulary>buddy-buddy</vocabulary>, so everyone can tell how close your friendship is.

仲良し describes close friends or people who get along really well. The word has a friendly, cute vibe and is often used for kids, families, or anyone with a warm bond.
reading_mnemonic: Both the readings here are kun'yomi, which you already know. Just be careful with 良 — in 良い, it can be read よ or い, but in 良し it's always read as よ.

examples.en: I ate a Neapolitan Spaghetti at the Western food restaurant.
examples.ja: 洋食レストランでナポリタンスパゲティを食べました。

examples.en: I'm working part-time at a so-called old fashioned Western family restaurant.
examples.ja: いわゆる昔ながらの洋食屋さんで、バイトをしています。

examples.en: Oh, did you eat the western-style lunch set at that restaurant? Hahaha. No wonder you still feel full.
examples.ja: ええっ！あそこのレストランで洋食ランチセットを食べたの？ははは。どおりでまだお腹がいっぱいなはずだわ。

meaning_mnemonic: Western-style eats just means Western-style food. You can call this Western food for short, but in Japan it actually refers to a Japanese genre of food inspired by European dishes. Think omurice (omelette rice) or Napolitan pasta (spaghetti and ketchup). You know, Western-style food.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I study Japanese every day.
examples.ja: 私は毎日日本語の勉強をします。

examples.en: Thank you so much. I've been learning a lot from you.
examples.ja: ありがとうございます！勉強になります。

examples.en: Keep up your English language studies. I’m always working on my Japanese too, so I know how hard it is.
examples.ja: 英語の勉強、頑張って下さいね。私も日本語をずっと勉強しているので苦労はよくわかります。

meaning_mnemonic: Your <kanji>exertion</kanji> is <kanji>strong</kanji>. You'd think this means you're working hard or something, but it means <vocabulary>studies</vocabulary> (like studies you have for a test or something). So for this, just imagine yourself exerting yourself really strongly on your homework. These are your <vocabulary>studies</vocabulary> / what you <vocabulary>study</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I hope I can start a warm family someday.
examples.ja: いつかは温かい家庭を作れたらな、と思ってます。

examples.en: Please leave out household waste here.
examples.ja: 家庭のゴミは、ここに出しておいてください。

examples.en: I didn't ask further, as I think each family has its own situation.
examples.ja: 家庭それぞれに事情があると思うので、それ以上は聞きませんでしたよ。

meaning_mnemonic: The essence of your <kanji>house</kanji> and <kanji>garden</kanji> is your <vocabulary>family</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>household</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>home</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: There are various kinds of herbs growing in the garden.
examples.ja: 色んなハーブが庭に生えています。

examples.en: A whole day is over, though all I did was weeding the garden.
examples.ja: 庭の草むしりで一日が終わってしまった。

examples.en: I have a beautiful garden but my neighbor’s chickens keep eating my flowers.
examples.ja: うちには美しい庭があるんだが、隣の人の鶏がいつも花を食べてしまうんだ。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. You can add the meaning <vocabulary>yard</vocabulary> to your memory bank as well, if you'd like.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You look at your garden. It doesn't meet your expectations so you decide it's time to get a <reading>newer</reading> (にわ) garden. Tear it all down, folks! Getting a newer garden, here!

examples.en: Your breath is so stinky that I could die.
examples.ja: あんたの息、死ぬほどくさいよ。

examples.en: You knocked the breath out of me!
examples.ja: びっくりしすぎて、息が止まるかと思ったよ。

examples.en: If you run around that much, you'll be out of breath!
examples.ja: そんなに走り回ったら息が切れるよ！

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You smell someone's <reading>icky</reading> (いき) <vocabulary>breath</vocabulary>. It's gross. Your skin crawls and your eyes roll back in your head from the icky, icky smell. You might die.

examples.en: My son is doing well.
examples.ja: 息子は元気です。

examples.en: My only son lives in an apartment around here.
examples.ja: この辺のアパートに私のひとり息子が住んでいます。

examples.en: I play with my son in the park at least twice a week.
examples.ja: 週に二回は息子と一緒に公園で遊びます。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>breath</kanji> <kanji>child</kanji> (that lets you release your breath when it's born) is a <vocabulary>son</vocabulary>. Nowadays it's cool to have a girl, but back in the day you wanted a son to carry on your underwater basket weaving legacy. That's why this is a son.
reading_mnemonic: The reading of this is messed up. 子 is こ, that should be okay. 息 is むす for some reason though. Why? Because you gave birth to a son, but he was a <reading>moose</reading> (むす). You better hold that breath again, because this is not what you wanted.

examples.en: The interest grew soon after.
examples.ja: すぐに利息が大きくなってしまった。

examples.en: I can't pay back the interest with my current job.
examples.ja: 今の仕事じゃ利息を返せないよ。

examples.en: I’m afraid there is no one here who can answer your question right now, but you can also check your interest rate online, if you can connect to the Internet.
examples.ja: あいにく今、その質問に答えられる者がいないのですが、もしインターネットにアクセス可能なら利息のレートはそちらでもご確認頂けますよ。

meaning_mnemonic: You receive <kanji>profit</kanji> at every <kanji>breath</kanji>. What kind of profit is this? It's <vocabulary>interest</vocabulary>. As time goes by and as you take more breaths you gain more bank interest.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I love traveling.
examples.ja: 私は旅が大好きです。

examples.en: I found a beautiful jewel on my trip.
examples.ja: 旅先で美しい宝石を見つけました。

examples.en: I tried some delicious snacks on my trip.
examples.ja: 旅先で美味しいおやつを試しました。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You are going on your <vocabulary>trip</vocabulary> but you need to bring your little <reading>tabby</reading> (たび) cat with you to keep you company. This cat keeps you calm and lets you leave your house, but the airlines won't let you take it on this trip. What to do?

examples.en: When do you go to Japan?
examples.ja: いつ日本へ旅行に行くんですか？

examples.en: Next month, I will go to Southeast Asia on a family trip.
examples.ja: 来月、家族旅行で東南アジアに行きます。

examples.en: I know you want to ask about my trip, but first things first, how have you been while I've been away?
examples.ja: 私の旅行の話を聞きたいのは分かるんだけど、それより、まずは私がいない間どうしてたのか教えてよ。

meaning_mnemonic: When you <kanji>go</kanji> on a <kanji>trip</kanji> you're taking a <vocabulary>trip</vocabulary>. This is <vocabulary>travel</vocabulary>. You should try to do this occasionally! Perhaps a nice 旅行 to Japan?
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: You can eat the roots of this flower.
examples.ja: この花の根は食べられますよ。

examples.en: The roots of the tree are coming through the basement.
examples.ja: 木の根が地下に入ってきてしまった。

examples.en: You might think he’s a great person but he’s really a horrible man at heart.
examples.ja: 彼は素敵な人だと思うかもしれないが、根がひどい男なのだ。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word:

This is a magic <vocabulary>root</vocabulary> that turns you into a horse. You take a bite and let out a loud <reading>neigh</reading> (ね)!

examples.en: My father and I have fundamentally the same way of thinking.
examples.ja: 私も父も根本の考え方は同じです。

examples.en: I want to relearn English from the ground up.
examples.ja: 英語を根本からもう一度学びなおしたいです。

examples.en: What do you think the fundamental cause of this problem is?
examples.ja: この問題の根本の原因はどこにあると思いますか？

meaning_mnemonic:
The <kanji>root</kanji> <kanji>origin</kanji> is the <vocabulary>root</vocabulary> of something. Possibly even more root than root, but we'll stick with root.

根本 generally refers to the root cause or fundamental <vocabulary>basis</vocabulary> of something, like "the root of the problem" or "the fundamental principle."
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Careful, 本 is ぽん, which is a weird rendaku. In case you need help with this rendaku reading, here's a mnemonic:

What's the <vocabulary>root</vocabulary> cause of your unhappiness? A <reading>pon</reading>y (ぽん). Getting a pony was basically the <vocabulary>basis</vocabulary> of all your childhood dreams. Unfortunately your parents couldn't afford a pony, so now you're in therapy. Oh yes, you still think of that pony, down there at the root of all your many, many issues…

examples.en: There are many birds on the roof.
examples.ja: 屋根の上にたくさんの鳥が止まっています。

examples.en: I'm happy to have a life with a roof and food.
examples.ja: 屋根も食べ物もある生活ができて、うれしいです。

examples.en: Please be careful as the snow may fall from the roof.
examples.ja: 屋根の上から雪が落ちるかもしれないので気を付けて下さいね。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>root</kanji> of your <kanji>roof</kanji> is still your <vocabulary>roof</vocabulary>. If it helps, imagine roots growing out of your roof. They protect you from the rain.
reading_mnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi readings. The kun'yomi for 根 is ね. For a mnemonic, we'll use the sound a horse makes, <reading>neigh</reading> (ね). Why is the horse neigh-ing? It's stuck on the <vocabulary>roof</vocabulary>.

examples.en: This job requires patience, huh?
examples.ja: これは根気のいる仕事だよな。

examples.en: This story is quite long, so you need some patience to complete it.
examples.ja: この物語はかなり長いので読み終えるには根気が必要です。

examples.en: Keep studying Japanese persistently and you’ll be fluent someday.
examples.ja: 根気よく日本語の勉強を続けていれば、いつかはペラペラになれるさ。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>root</kanji> of your <kanji>energy</kanji>. You have to dig deep into your energy, all the way to the origin and source of it, to have enough <vocabulary>patience</vocabulary> to deal with this dumb kid who's eating away at your not-root energy. It's all you have, and you need to use it.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Daikon is often used in Japanese cuisine.
examples.ja: 大根は和食によく使われます。

examples.en: I bought daikon pickles.
examples.ja: 大根のピクルスを買ってきた。

examples.en: If you cook nimono with daikon, it goes well with fish or eggs.
examples.ja: 大根は煮物にすると魚や卵との相性が良いですよ。

meaning_mnemonic: This will be easier if you've seen or heard of daikon before. It's a really <kanji>big</kanji> <kanji>root</kanji> in the ground that's pretty delicious. It's known as <vocabulary>daikon</vocabulary> in the grocery stores for the most part, though occasionally you'll see it as <vocabulary>Japanese radish</vocabulary> instead.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. 大 uses the だい reading because if you try to put the whole thing in your mouth at once you'll probably end up choking and <reading>dy</reading>ing.

examples.en: Flush the toilet after using it.
examples.ja: トイレは使ったら水を流しましょう。

examples.en: "Nagashi somen" is where you flow somen noodles through a bamboo tube and eat it.
examples.ja: そうめんを竹に流して食べるのが「流しそうめん」です。

examples.en: Are you not even grateful to the workers who sweat and work every day?
examples.ja: 毎日汗を流して働く労働者たちに感謝の気持ちもないのか？

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>stream</kanji>. If you're streaming water, it might be <vocabulary>to flush something</vocabulary>. Alternatively, <vocabulary>to pour something</vocabulary> makes a stream of liquid, and <vocabulary>to set something afloat</vocabulary> is to make something flow in the stream.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

What do you do with someone who is a <reading>nagger</reading> (one who nags)? You have <vocabulary>to flush</vocabulary> them down the toilet. Imagine someone nagging you to do your chores so you flush them down the toilet, somehow.

examples.en: Shopping malls sell trendy clothes.
examples.ja: ショッピングモールでは流行の服を売っています。

examples.en: A mullet is one of the trendy hairstyles.
examples.ja: マレットは流行のヘアスタイルの一つです。

examples.en: Apparently influenza is prevalent among the elderly this year.
examples.ja: この冬、お年寄りの間にインフルエンザが流行しているらしい。

meaning_mnemonic: Where the <kanji>stream</kanji> is <kanji>go</kanji>ing is where everyone's going. That's what tends to be the <vocabulary>trend</vocabulary> of things. Imagine a trend going on in your society right now. Imagine it going down a stream with everyone following it. This word is also used for less desirable trends, like the <vocabulary>prevalence</vocabulary> of infectious diseases.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: That's something only first-rate pianists can do.
examples.ja: さすが、一流のピアニストは違うね。

examples.en: My father is a first-class pianist and has many fans.
examples.ja: 父は一流のピアニストで、たくさんのファンがいます。

examples.en: It doesn't matter if it's first class or second class. I just love your work.
examples.ja: 一流だろうが二流だろうが関係ない。私はあなたの作品を愛しているんです。

meaning_mnemonic: This is a weird one. You have <kanji>one</kanji> <kanji>stream</kanji>. This is <vocabulary>first rate</vocabulary> stream material we have here, though. If you think about it, if you only have one stream (instead of a ton of streams), you can put all your effort and energy into it. When you do that, you're making sure it is a <vocabulary>first rate</vocabulary> stream in terms of quality and anything else.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Apparently, the main stream of the Amazon River is colored brown.
examples.ja: アマゾン川の本流は水が茶色いそうですよ。

examples.en: It looks like the same style as the mainstream to me.
examples.ja: 私にとっては本流のスタイルと同じように見えます。

examples.en: When you say mainstream Japanese literature, who is the first author that comes to mind?
examples.ja: 日本文学の本流と言って、最初に思い浮かぶのは誰ですか。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>origin</kanji> <kanji>stream</kanji>, that's where everything comes from. That is the <vocabulary>mainstream</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I'm planning to remove this illustration.
examples.ja: このイラストを消す予定です。

examples.en: I erased all the data by mistake.
examples.ja: 間違えてデータを全部消しちゃったんだよ。

examples.en: After you leave the classroom, please don’t forget to turn off the light.
examples.ja: 教室を出た後は電気を消すのを忘れないで下さい。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>extinguish</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to extinguish something</vocabulary>. You can also use this word to say <vocabulary>to erase something</vocabulary>, like data, and <vocabulary>to turn something off</vocabulary>, like the lights or the power. Technically you're extinguishing the data, as well as the lights or power, right?
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You have <vocabulary>to extinguish</vocabulary> the fire! The <reading>ke</reading>ttle (け) got too hot, and it caught on fire.

examples.en: I want to increase sales by five times before the end of the year.
examples.ja: 年末までに売り上げを去年の五倍にしたいんです。

examples.en: Make it at least seven times more before you give me back this money.
examples.ja: このお金、最低でも七倍にして返してよね。

examples.en: Since the introduction and subsequent spread of conveyer belt sushi shops, salmon consumption in Japan has tripled.
examples.ja: 回転寿司の普及に伴い、日本におけるサーモンの消費量は輸入開始から三倍となった。

meaning_mnemonic: Throw this onto a number and you have yourself the number of <vocabulary>times</vocabulary> something has increased. For example, ３倍 means something increased "three fold."
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Omit the 〜 when writing out the answer, though. That just represents that there should be something before the kanji in this word when being used.

examples.en: I had some coffee in a cup that's twice as big as my usual cup.
examples.ja: いつもの二倍の大きさのカップでコーヒーを飲みました。

examples.en: Can you double the volume on the TV?
examples.ja: テレビのボリュームを二倍にしてくれませんか？

examples.en: Wow! Your brother weighs twice as much as you, huh?
examples.ja: うわ！君のお兄さんって、君の二倍の体重があるんだね！

meaning_mnemonic: Something that is <kanji>two</kanji> <kanji>times</kanji> is <vocabulary>double</vocabulary> (or it is just simply <vocabulary>two times</vocabulary>). Of course, this all works with things like 三倍, 百倍, and 四十二倍 as well.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: There is no staff at the cash register.
examples.ja: レジに店員がいない。

examples.en: Let's ask the staff about the menu.
examples.ja: 店員さんにメニューについて聞いてみよう。

examples.en: That shop employee was a real kidder, wasn't he?
examples.ja: あの店員さん、とってもお茶目だったね。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>shop</kanji> <kanji>member</kanji> is someone who is a "member" (aka employed by) the shop. This is the <vocabulary>shop staff</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: All of the band members are men.
examples.ja: バンドメンバーの全員が男です。

examples.en: They decided that every Tofugu employee will take the bacon sommelier exam.
examples.ja: トーフグの社員は、全員がベーコンソムリエのテストを受けることになりました。

examples.en: We have meals together as a whole family.
examples.ja: うちは家族全員で一緒に食事します。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>All</kanji> <kanji>member</kanji>s means <vocabulary>all members</vocabulary>. This is also a fancy way to say <vocabulary>everybody</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: The other day, a new employee joined the company.
examples.ja: 先日、新しい社員が入社しました。

examples.en: Employees will be at the office by nine o'clock every morning.
examples.ja: 社員たちは毎朝、九時には出社します。

examples.en: The employees in this company are all weird and wonderful.
examples.ja: この会社の社員は、全員奇抜で素晴らしい。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>company</kanji> <kanji>members</kanji> are the <vocabulary>employees</vocabulary> and the <vocabulary>staff</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: My father is a company employee.
examples.ja: 父は会社員です。

examples.en: We're people before we are employees.
examples.ja: わたしたちはみんな、会社員である前に、一人の人間なんですよ。

examples.en: That employee got busted for drug possession.
examples.ja: あの会社員は麻薬所持で逮捕された。

meaning_mnemonic: A "company" (会社) <kanji>member</kanji> is someone who works at a company. This is a <vocabulary>company employee</vocabulary>. There are many of these in Japan. Most of them are drunk.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Hiroshima is famous for oysters.
examples.ja: 広島はカキで有名です。

examples.en: I'm heading into the city from Hiroshima airport by city bus.
examples.ja: 広島空港から市バスで市内に向かってるところです。

examples.en: The atomic bombs dropped on Hiroshima and Nagasaki instantly killed more than 100,000 people.
examples.ja: 広島と長崎に投下された原爆は、一瞬で十万人以上の人々の命を奪った。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>wide</kanji> <kanji>island</kanji>... this isn't helpful on its own, but this wide island is <vocabulary>Hiroshima</vocabulary> (heard of it?). When you do the reading it will make more sense.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the kun'yomi readings of both of these which is what you learned with the individual kanji. Just make sure you know those readings and you'll be able to read this.

examples.en: We participate in this town's festival every year.
examples.ja: 私たちは毎年この町の祭に出ます。

examples.en: Today is the day of the festival that happens once a year.
examples.ja: 今日は一年一度の祭りの日です。

examples.en: Many Japanese festivals have connections to Buddhism or Shintoism.
examples.ja: 日本の多くのお祭は、仏教や神道と結びついています。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic:
While at a <vocabulary>festival</vocabulary>, a guy named Matt has to go to the bathroom. <reading>Matt’s uri</reading>ne (まつり) has been filling up his bladder ever since he began drinking that 64oz cup of soda. Matt’s urine is ready to bust out at any moment. He really has to go to the bathroom.

This word can also be written 祭り, and the pronunciation stays the same.

examples.en: My younger brother needs exercises for reading comprehension.
examples.ja: 弟には文章を読むエクササイズが必要です。

examples.en: Koichi is such a good writer.
examples.ja: コウイチは文章が本当に上手だ。

examples.en: That person's writing style feels a bit pompous to me.
examples.ja: あの人の文章って少し気取っていると思うんだよね。

meaning_mnemonic:
A <kanji>writing</kanji> <kanji>chapter</kanji> is just another name for a piece of <vocabulary>writing</vocabulary>, a.k.a. a <vocabulary>composition</vocabulary>. Even if it's only a single <vocabulary>sentence</vocabulary>! 文章 covers just about every type of writing there is.

Although 文章 is pretty versatile, it most often refers to a complete piece of longer writing, like an essay, novel, short story, or poem. But even something super short like a tanka or haiku can be called 文章, as long as it's a complete work by itself.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Chapter one was good, but two was meh.
examples.ja: 第一章はおもしろかったけど、第二章はいまいちだった。

examples.en: The second chapter of my life will begin soon.
examples.ja: もうすぐ人生の第二章が始まります。

examples.en: No way! Are you reading that book too? I’ve just finished chapter two. Don’t tell me anything if you’re farther than me.
examples.ja: まじで？君もその本読んでるの？俺、昨日ちょうど第二章読み終わったところなんだけど。もしそれより先に進んでるなら、何も言わないでね。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>ordinal number prefix</kanji> <kanji>two</kanji> <kanji>chapter</kanji> has a much simpler way of describing it, which is <vocabulary>chapter two</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Please think of your safety first.
examples.ja: 自分の安全を第一に考えて下さい。

examples.en: The number one reason I want to take a break is that I don't have enough time.
examples.ja: 休みたい第一の理由は時間が足りないからです。

examples.en: What was your first impression of each other?
examples.ja: お互いの第一印象はどうでしたか？

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>ordinal number prefix</kanji> <kanji>one</kanji> refers to <vocabulary>the first</vocabulary> thing. This is the <vocabulary>number one</vocabulary> place you can get. In fact, it's simply the <vocabulary>best</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: This work got first place in the writing contest.
examples.ja: この作品は作文コンクールで第一位でした。

examples.en: If he wins that game, he'll become first in the world rankings.
examples.ja: もしその試合に勝ったら、彼は世界ランキング第一位になります。

examples.en: Even though we have been first place in sales at the company until now, it is likely that a newcomer will take our spot.
examples.ja: 今までずっと社内で売り上げ第一位だったのに、新人にその座を取られそうです。

meaning_mnemonic: You have the <kanji>ordinal number prefix</kanji> and 一位 (first place). By adding the prefix 第, you can make it a little more formal, but it still means <vocabulary>first place</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Tokyo is a city in Japan.
examples.ja: 東京都は日本の都市です。

examples.en: There are many people who want to live in the Tokyo prefecture.
examples.ja: 東京都に住みたがる人は多いですよ。

examples.en: Taro Yamada (pseudonym), who is in his 30s and a salaryman in the Tokyo Metropolis, told us this in the interview.
examples.ja: 東京都の３０代会社員、山田さん（仮名）は、インタビューでこう語りました。

meaning_mnemonic:
Remember how 東京 is Tokyo? Add <kanji>metropolis</kanji> to it and you get the <vocabulary>Tokyo Metropolis</vocabulary>.

東京都 is basically one of Japan's prefectures, but they call it a "metropolis" instead. It's the capital and the largest city in all of Japan!
reading_mnemonic: The reading is just 東京 and the on'yomi for 都 (と), which you learned with the kanji. In other words, on'yomi for all three kanji here.

examples.en: Kyoto is a famous place in Japan.
examples.ja: 京都は日本の名所です。

examples.en: I'm planning to go enjoy cherry blossom viewing in Kyoto in April.
examples.ja: 四月に京都で花見を楽しむ予定だ。

examples.en: We are planning to eat yuba after seeing some famous temples in Kyoto.
examples.ja: 京都では有名なお寺を見物した後、湯葉を食べる予定です。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>capital</kanji> <kanji>metropolis</kanji> back in the day was <vocabulary>Kyoto</vocabulary>. Now of course the capital is Tokyo, but kanji doesn't know this. That's why Kyoto is the capital metropolis!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Something moved over there.
examples.ja: あそこで何か動いたよ。

examples.en: Tofugu's servers operate twenty-four hours a day, so it can always be accessed.
examples.ja: トーフグのサーバーは二十四時間動いているので、いつでもアクセスできますよ。

examples.en: Shoot! My computer doesn’t work. How did this happen?!
examples.ja: くそ〜。パソコンが動かなくなっちゃったぜ。どうしてこうなったんだろう？！

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>move</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to move</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Someone is telling you <vocabulary>to move</vocabulary>. They are saying "<reading>you go</reading> (うご) over there. Move! Move!" If it helps, have them pronounce "You go" more like "Ugo."

examples.en: I don't like animals.
examples.ja: 動物は苦手なんです。

examples.en: Are there large animals living around here?
examples.ja: この辺に大きな動物は住んでいますか？

examples.en: At the zoo, you can see wild animals up close.
examples.ja: 動物園では野生動物も近くで見ることができます。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>moving</kanji> <kanji>thing</kanji>... think about the "things" that move. Technically it could be a lot of things (aka basically anything), but in this case we are talking about moving living things. We won't include humans, because humans are too good to be called things. This refers to <vocabulary>animals</vocabulary> instead.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I actually want to exercise more, but I don't have time.
examples.ja: 本当はもっと運動したいけど、時間がないんだよね。

examples.en: I am not exercising enough these days.
examples.ja: 最近、運動不足なんですよ。

examples.en: Beer after exercising is the best.
examples.ja: 運動した後のビールは最高です。

meaning_mnemonic:
When you <kanji>carry</kanji> your <kanji>move</kanji>ments (or carry something along with your movements, like weights, for example) you are doing <vocabulary>exercise</vocabulary>. Speaking of which, perhaps you've been studying kanji a little too much lately. Time to get up and do some squats or play some <vocabulary>sport</vocabulary>s.

This word can also mean more abstract kinds of <vocabulary>movement</vocabulary>, like social or political movements that strive for change. It can also be used when describing <vocabulary>motion</vocabulary> in physics.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Mr. Tanaka succeeded in business.
examples.ja: 田中さんは商売で大きく成功しました。

examples.en: Business has dried up recently because of that convenience store.
examples.ja: 最近はあのコンビニのせいで、商売あがったりだね。

examples.en: After leaving school I went into business for myself, but I soon learned that running a business is no easy task.
examples.ja: 学校卒業後に商売を始めたんですが、すぐに商売をすることは簡単ではないことを学びました。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Sell</kanji>ing <kanji>merchandise</kanji> is <vocabulary>business</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>commerce</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>trade</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You've learned them both already!

examples.en: This was a merchant's house a long time ago.
examples.ja: ここは昔、商人の家でした。

examples.en: There are many merchants in the town.
examples.ja: 町には商人がたくさんいます。

examples.en: He said he was a merchant, but he was actually homeless, and his job was collecting empty cans.
examples.ja: 彼、自分が商人だって言ってたんだけど、実はホームレスで、仕事は空き缶収集だったの。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>merchandise</kanji> <kanji>person</kanji> is a <vocabulary>merchant</vocabulary>. You want to buy something or you just looking?
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: The restaurant over there has good food, but the service is bad.
examples.ja: あそこのレストラン、味は良いけどサービスが悪いよな。

examples.en: I thought I was having a bad dream.
examples.ja: 悪い夢でも見てるのかと思った。

examples.en: The milk went bad, but I didn’t care.
examples.ja: 牛乳は悪くなっていたけど、俺は気にしなかった。

meaning_mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>bad</kanji>? It's also <vocabulary>bad</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

Do you know how in the Mario universe all the <vocabulary>bad</vocabulary> versions are called "<reading>WARU</reading>" (わる)? For example: "WARUIJI" and "WARIO." That's because they are bad. They come from this kanji. So, if you ever need to remember this reading, just think back to Wario and Waruigi.

examples.en: He's a bad guy, but he's a gardening professional who loves flowers.
examples.ja: あいつは悪人だが、花が大好きなガーデニングのプロなんだ。

examples.en: Nobody in the world was born a vicious person.
examples.ja: この世界に生まれつきの悪人なんていないよ。

examples.en: Do you really think it’s possible to differentiate between good people and bad people?
examples.ja: お前、本当に善人と悪人を区別することが可能だと思っているのか？

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>bad</kanji> <kanji>person</kanji> is a <vocabulary>bad person</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: That bitch sure has good ears!
examples.ja: あの悪女、耳だけはいいんだよな。

examples.en: She is a wicked woman, but is always on time.
examples.ja: かの女は悪女だが、いつも時間はきっちり守る。

examples.en: The evil woman took my breath away. I was crazy about her.
examples.ja: その悪女は息をのむほど美しかった。僕は彼女に夢中だった。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>bad</kanji> <kanji>woman</kanji> is an <vocabulary>evil woman</vocabulary>. Surprisingly, "mother in law" is not one of the meanings for this word.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Today was the worst day ever.
examples.ja: 今日は最悪な一日だったよ。

examples.en: If worst comes to worst,​ I at least want to take a day off from work tomorrow.
examples.ja: 最悪、明日だけでも会社を休みたいんですが。

examples.en: "My car was stolen last night." "Oh, no! That’s the worst!"
examples.ja: 「昨夜、自動車を盗まれちゃったんだよ。」「げっ、最悪じゃん。」

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>most</kanji> <kanji>bad</kanji> is <vocabulary>the worst</vocabulary>. At least it can’t get any worse…
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: How long ago was the last time we ate breakfast as a family?
examples.ja: 家族で朝ごはんを食べるなんて、何年ぶりだろう？

examples.en: I'm planning to go to the park with my family today.
examples.ja: 今日は家族と公園に行く予定です。

examples.en: Going on a family trip to Hawaii is how rich Japanese families spend their New Year's.
examples.ja: ハワイに家族旅行に行くのが日本の金持ちの正月の過ごし方です。

meaning_mnemonic: Your <kanji>house</kanji> <kanji>tribe</kanji> is your <vocabulary>family</vocabulary>. They live in the same house as you and they're part of your "tribe." This is closer than family, though (depending on how you look at family). This is your <vocabulary>immediate family</vocabulary> because these are the people you live with and give birth to, etc.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Various ethnic groups live in Singapore.
examples.ja: シンガポールには様々な民族が住んでいます。

examples.en: I want to learn about the culture of the Ainu people.
examples.ja: アイヌ民族の文化について学びたいです。

examples.en: India has a lot of ethnic diversity but I wonder if all of them still eat curry.
examples.ja: インドには多様な民族がいますが、みんながみんなカレーを食べるのでしょうか。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>peoples</kanji> <kanji>tribe</kanji> (or tribe of peoples) is a group that all stick together. They are one single <vocabulary>ethnic group</vocabulary>. What's your 民族?
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: The sunglasses have fallen into a deep pond.
examples.ja: サングラスが深い池に落ちてしまった。

examples.en: I heard you letting out a deep sigh, what happened?
examples.ja: そんなに深いため息ついて、どうしたの？

examples.en: Is it true that fish tend to maintain a deep connection with their parents, siblings, and high school friends?
examples.ja: 魚たちが、親や兄弟、高校時代の友人たちとの深い繋がりを保っていることが多いって、本当ですか？

meaning_mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>deep</kanji>? It's also <vocabulary>deep</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. Because the reading sounds just like a dirty word, and there may be innocent children about, I'll let you come up with your own mnemonic for this one. Maybe someone pushes you into a deep hole that will surely kill you so you yell something out as you fall down it?

examples.en: What's up this late at night?
examples.ja: こんな深夜に、どうしたの？

examples.en: This is a bar where you can enjoy music and alcohol until late at night.
examples.ja: ここは深夜にお酒と音楽を楽しめるバーです。

examples.en: How many friends do you have that you can call even at midnight?
examples.ja: 深夜に電話できる友人は何人くらいいますか？

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>deep</kanji> <kanji>night</kanji> is the <vocabulary>middle of the night</vocabulary>. It doesn't get any deeper than that before you start coming out of the night to start the next day.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You've seen these readings before, but the や reading for 夜 is still pretty new, so here's a mnemonic refresher:

What do you do in the <vocabulary>middle of the night</vocabulary>? You watch the <reading>Ya</reading>nkees (や). You should be asleep, but instead you're up watching baseball highlights from the Yankees <vocabulary>late at night</vocabulary>.

examples.en: It's one hundred feet deep here.
examples.ja: ここは水深100フィートです。

examples.en: The depth of this river is ten meters.
examples.ja: この川の水深は十メートルです。

examples.en: I like swimming in a shallow pool.
examples.ja: 水深が浅いプールで泳ぐのが好きです。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>water</kanji> <kanji>deep</kanji>ness is the <vocabulary>water depth</vocabulary>. You should check this before diving into the water so you don't hit your face.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: The depth of the water is 300 meters at its deepest point.
examples.ja: 水深は最深で３００mもある。

examples.en: Around here is the deepest area.
examples.ja: ここら辺が最深のエリアです。

examples.en: Sognefjord is the longest and deepest fjord in the world.
examples.ja: ソグネフィヨルドは、世界最長・最深のフィヨルドです。

meaning_mnemonic:
The <kanji>most</kanji> <kanji>deep</kanji> is the <vocabulary>deepest</vocabulary>.

最深 is a formal word used in geology to describe the deepest point of things like caves and oceans.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Dammit! I hit the ball into a bunker.
examples.ja: ああっ！球がバンカーに入っちゃったよ。

examples.en: Hey, I bought a new ball for baseball. Do you want to play catch with me?
examples.ja: ねぇ、新しい野球の球を買ったんだけど、一緒にキャッチボールしない？

examples.en: What was the formula for the volume of a sphere?
examples.ja: 球の体積を求める公式って何だっけ？

meaning_mnemonic:
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

球 has a slightly technical sound and highlights the sphere shape of the object you're talking about. It's most commonly used to refer to <vocabulary>sports ball</vocabulary>s (as a more formal alternative to ボール).
reading_mnemonic:
This word is made up of a single kanji, so it should use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You see a <vocabulary>sphere</vocabulary> in <reading>Tama</reading>ra's (たま) hand. You're not totally sure what it is, but it's really spherical. Maybe it's some kind of <vocabulary>sports ball</vocabulary>. Remember Tamara, the local ball girl? It would totally make sense for Tamara to be holding either a sphere or a sports ball, since that's kind of all she does.

You might notice 球 has the same reading as the vocab word 玉. Their meanings are kind of similar too, so this reading should be a bit easier to remember!

examples.en: I'm on my way to go see a professional baseball game now.
examples.ja: これから、プロ野球のゲームを見に行くところなんです。

examples.en: I've never been a pitcher in baseball.
examples.ja: 野球で投手をしたことはないんです。

examples.en: I plan to play a sandlot baseball game this weekend with some people from my company.
examples.ja: 今週末に会社の人たちと草野球の試合をする予定です。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Field</kanji> <kanji>Sphere</kanji>! The greatest sport to grace this earth since a very similar (aka the same) sport, <vocabulary>baseball</vocabulary>. Think about it, you play on a field and you use a little sphere. Awesome!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: This fairy tale is popular with small children.
examples.ja: この童話は小さい子たちに人気があります。

examples.en: I feel like I'm in a fairy tale world.
examples.ja: まるで童話の世界に入ってしまった気分です。

examples.en: Many children's stories have happy endings, but the one I'm writing is a little dark.
examples.ja: ハッピーエンディングの童話が多いですが、私が書いている童話は少しダークな物語です。

meaning_mnemonic: Don't think of this as a <kanji>juvenile</kanji> <kanji>talk</kanji>. Think of 話 the vocab word, which means "story." If you do that, you get a "juvenile story." What's a juvenile story? It's a <vocabulary>children's story</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: There are many shops on the first floor.
examples.ja: 一階にはお店がたくさんあります。

examples.en: After cleaning this floor, will you come to the first floor?
examples.ja: このフロアのクリーニングが終わったら、一階に来てくれる？

examples.en: The bathroom is next to the exit on the first floor.
examples.ja: トイレは一階の出口の横にあります。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>one</kanji> <kanji>floor</kanji> is the <vocabulary>first floor</vocabulary> (or <vocabulary>floor one</vocabulary>). In Japan, that means the <vocabulary>ground floor</vocabulary>. Pretty simple.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is on'yomi because it's a jukugo kanji. Be careful of the 一 though. It gets shortened and has a little っ in there.

examples.en: You can hear people on the second floor saying something loud.
examples.ja: 二階に住む人が大声で何かを言ってるのが聞こえます。

examples.en: If you are looking for the dentist, it is on the second floor of this building.
examples.ja: 歯医者さんなら、このビルの二階にあります。

examples.en: The second floor has bedrooms, and the rest is on the first floor.
examples.ja: 二階はベッドルームで、あとは全部一階にあります。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>two</kanji> <kanji>floor</kanji> is the <vocabulary>second floor</vocabulary>. In Japan, that means the floor above the ground floor. Going up!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Let's race to the forty-second floor!
examples.ja: 四十二階まで競争よ！

examples.en: Going to the forty-second floor on the elevator takes some time.
examples.ja: 四十二階まで行くのはエレベーターでも時間がかかります。

examples.en: It’s pretty annoying that there’s a lot of bureaucratic red tape involved in moving, and to make matters worse, sometimes the person in charge has an attitude problem. However, the worst part of my moving this time was that the elevator was out of service when I moved in and my apartment was on the forty-second floor.
examples.ja: 引っ越しって、色々事務手続きがあって結構面倒くさい上に、対応の悪い担当者とかもいたりするよね。でも、今回の引っ越しで最悪だったのは、引っ越しの日にエレベーターが故障中だったことだよ。俺の部屋、四十二階なのに。

meaning_mnemonic: You know that 四十二 means "forty two." So, as long as you know <kanji>floor</kanji> you'll know this means <vocabulary>forty-second floor</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: It is very cold today.
examples.ja: 今日はとても寒いです。

examples.en: I had to wait an hour in this cold for the bus.
examples.ja: この寒い中、一時間もバスを待たなきゃならなかったんだよ。

examples.en: I’m going to Hawaii not only to escape the cold, but to see my family.
examples.ja: 僕がハワイに行くのは、寒さから逃れるためだけではなく家族に会うためでもあります。

meaning_mnemonic:
This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>cold</kanji>? It's <vocabulary>cold</vocabulary>.

寒い is used specifically for when you feel cold. You can say it when you're outside on a chilly winter day, for example, or when you walk into a cold room. It can even be used as a response to unfunny jokes that leave you cold.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading which you learned with the kanji (<reading>Samu</reading>rai (さむ)). Remember?

examples.en: It's very hot today, isn't it?
examples.ja: 今日はとても暑いですね。

examples.en: It has been hot these days in Japan.
examples.ja: 日本では、このところ暑い日がつづいています。

examples.en: The summer in Japan is too hot, so I'm going to Canada from July to August.
examples.ja: 日本の夏は暑すぎるから、七月と八月はカナダに行くよ。

meaning_mnemonic: This is the adjective form of <kanji>hot</kanji>... but we're going to call it <vocabulary>hot weather</vocabulary>. Why? Because there's a difference between something that's hot and the weather or atmosphere being hot. This is that kind of hot, as in..."Damn, man, it's hot out here!"
reading_mnemonic: This uses the same reading as the one you learned with the kanji, so you're good to go here!

examples.en: I expected more from the grad student.
examples.ja: あの大学院生には、もっと期待してたのに。

examples.en: The cup ramen that I got sent from Japan the other day was disappointing.
examples.ja: この前わざわざ日本から送ってもらったカップラーメンは期待外れでした。

examples.en: Wall Street always needs top-level talent and I’m pretty sure that Koichi will be able to live up to those expectations.
examples.ja: ウォール・ストリートは常にトップレベルの人材を求めていますが、コウイチならきっとそこでも期待に応えられると思います。

meaning_mnemonic:
For a <kanji>period of time</kanji> you have to <kanji>wait</kanji>. During this waiting period, you’re building up an <vocabulary>expectation</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>anticipation</vocabulary> for something to happen a certain way. Waiting, expecting, waiting, expecting…

期待 specifically refers to the feeling of expectation or anticipation for a desired outcome.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Once the semester is over, the summer vacation will begin.
examples.ja: 学期が終わると、夏休みが始まります。

examples.en: It's a new semester from next week on.
examples.ja: 来週から新しい学期だ。

examples.en: Final exams are held in March so there's still plenty of time to prepare.
examples.ja: 学期末試験は三月なので、まだまだ勉強する時間はたっぷりあります。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>study</kanji> <kanji>period of time</kanji> isn't the pitiful amount of time you spend studying. It's something much bigger: the <vocabulary>school term</vocabulary>. Ugh, how much longer is this study period of time???
reading_mnemonic: The reading is on'yomi because it's a jukugo word but がく gets shortened to がっ, so be careful. Maybe you just wish the school term would get shorter which is why you shortened がく like that?

examples.en: Finally, the snowboarding and skiing season for this year has come.
examples.ja: やっと今年もスノーボードとスキーの時期が来ましたね。

examples.en: It's time for a typhoon soon.
examples.ja: もうすぐ台風の時期ですね。

examples.en: If you've just gone abroad, isn't it the time to feel cultural shock?
examples.ja: 海外に行ったばかりなら、カルチャーショックを受ける時期じゃない？

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>time</kanji> <kanji>period of time</kanji> is a period of time of time. If anything, just notice how many times the word "time" is used and you'll remember this word means <vocabulary>time</vocabulary>. The meaning is a specific type of time, though. This is talking about a <vocabulary>season</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>period</vocabulary> of time, not the concept of time itself. That would be 時間 or something.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: There are various plants growing in this forest.
examples.ja: この森には色々な植物が生えてますね。

examples.en: I like plants better than animals.
examples.ja: 私は動物よりも植物の方が好きなんです。

examples.en: This plant requires a lot of water.
examples.ja: この植物は水をたくさん必要とします。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Plant</kanji> <kanji>things</kanji> are <vocabulary>plants</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>vegetation</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji.

examples.en: It's better to go see a dentist at least once every six months.
examples.ja: 半年に一度は歯医者に行った方がいい。

examples.en: I have a dentist appointment at two o'clock today.
examples.ja: 今日は二時から歯医者です。

examples.en: I want to be a dentist when I grow up.
examples.ja: 大きくなったら歯医者になりたい。

meaning_mnemonic: You know that a 医者 is a doctor. So what is a <kanji>tooth</kanji> doctor? A <vocabulary>dentist</vocabulary>. Seriously, don't forget to floss. 歯医者 hate when you forget to floss.
reading_mnemonic: You know how to read 歯 and 医者, so you should be good to go!

examples.en: Oh, you have three bad teeth.
examples.ja: あっ、虫歯が三本もありますよ。

examples.en: Do you have a cavity again?
examples.ja: また虫歯になっちゃったの？

examples.en: Prevention is the key to tooth decay.
examples.ja: 虫歯は予防が大切です。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>tooth</kanji> <kanji>bug</kanji>... Luckily, it's not some bug living in your tooth, though you can see why someone might think this is what happens. A tooth with a "bug" in it is a tooth with a <vocabulary>cavity</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The readings are both kun'yomi, but those are the readings you learned with these kanji. Notice that は turns to ば, though. Presumably this is because you might yell out "BAH!" when you find out you have a cavity.

examples.en: The baby's teeth are growing
examples.ja: 赤ちゃんに歯が生えてきました。

examples.en: My father's teeth turned yellow due to smoking cigarettes.
examples.ja: タバコのせいで私の父の歯は黄色くなってしまった。

examples.en: I’m thinking about buying one of those electric toothbrushes, but they’re so expensive.
examples.ja: 電動歯ブラシを買うことを考えているんだが、どれも値段が高いんだよね。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: The reading that you learned with the kanji is the same as this one. <reading>HA!</reading> Take that, kanji.

examples.en: My mother's hands are always warm.
examples.ja: 母の手はいつも温かい。

examples.en: I want to drink warm tea.
examples.ja: 温かいお茶が飲みたいなぁ。

examples.en: I'm a beginner, so please go easy on me.
examples.ja: 初心者なので、どうか温かい目で見守ってください。

meaning_mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>warm</kanji>? It's <vocabulary>warm</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

Touch something that's warm... too warm! You pull your hand back and go "<reading>AH ta-ta!</reading> (あたた). People make this noise when they touch something that's hot, I hear. It's almost like saying "hot hot hot" while dropping the "h" sound.

People often pronounce this as あったかい, especially in casual, spoken Japanese. The "correct" reading is still あたたかい though, so keep that in mind when you're trying to type the kanji or taking an important test!

examples.en: This onsen is open for people with tattoos too.
examples.ja: この温泉は、タトゥーのある人も入れますよ。

examples.en: I will go on a hot spring trip with my friends this weekend.
examples.ja: 今週末、友人と温泉旅行に行きます。

examples.en: Neither my dad nor mom likes hot springs.
examples.ja: 私の父も母も温泉が好きじゃありません。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>warm</kanji> <kanji>spring</kanji> (like the water kind of spring) is a <vocabulary>hot spring</vocabulary>. These are really nice. You should go to them in Japan.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: What's the temperature of the water?
examples.ja: この水の温度は何度ですか。

examples.en: Can you raise the temperature on the AC up to 24℃?
examples.ja: エアコンの温度を二十四度まで上げてもらえませんか？

examples.en: There's a huge gap in enthusiasm between my father and mother.
examples.ja: 父と母の温度差が激しい。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>warm</kanji> <kanji>degree</kanji>s is how many degrees warm it is in here. Of course, there can be very few warm degrees as well, making it very cold. What is all this? It's the <vocabulary>temperature</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: My mother came to the airport for me.
examples.ja: 母は空港まで来てくれました。

examples.en: Today, I went to the airport to see off my French friends.
examples.ja: 今日は空港までフランス人の友人を見送りに行きました。

examples.en: I think I left my passport in the car I rented at the airport.
examples.ja: 空港で借りた車の中に、パスポートを忘れた気がする。

meaning_mnemonic: Put aside your steampunk blimp fantasies for a moment. A <kanji>sky</kanji> <kanji>harbor</kanji> is an <vocabulary>airport</vocabulary>, nothing more.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Tea ceremony is an important part of Japanese culture.
examples.ja: 茶の湯は日本の文化の大切な一部です。

examples.en: I'm looking for a shop where I can buy tools for tea ceremonies.
examples.ja: 茶の湯の道具が買えるお店をさがしています。

examples.en: In the world of tea ceremonies there is a saying, "Ichi-go ichi-e," which means "to treasure every encounter." This saying was also used as the subtitle for Japan’s release of Forrest Gump.
examples.ja: 茶の湯の世界には、「一つ一つの出会いを大切に」という意味の「一期一会」という言葉があります。この言葉は、映画「フォレスト・ガンプ」の副タイトルとしても使われました。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>hot water</kanji> of <kanji>tea</kanji>. That is part of the ceremony that goes into the <vocabulary>tea ceremony</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The readings are both the readings you learned with the kanji. Now you can spend a little more time drinking tea at a tea ceremony and a little less time trying to remember kanji readings.

examples.en: Steam is coming out of the kettle.
examples.ja: ケトルから湯気が出てるよ。

examples.en: Be careful of the steam.
examples.ja: 湯気に気を付けてね。

examples.en: To make good sushi rice, using a paddle, you must mix vinegar into steaming hot, freshly cooked rice.
examples.ja: 美味しい寿司飯を作るには、しゃもじを使って、湯気が立つ炊きたての熱いごはんに酢を混ぜる必要があります。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Hot water</kanji>'s <kanji>energy</kanji> isn't the hot water itself, it's what comes out of it (when it's boiling, for example). This is the <vocabulary>steam</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>vapor</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
The ゆ part of the reading makes sense. The げ part for 気 is a bit of an exception, so here's a mnemonic to help with that:

No creature likes <vocabulary>steam</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>vapor</vocabulary> more than <reading>ge</reading>ckos (げ). Geckos live in hot places, so wherever you see steam, you'll be sure to see at least one gecko nearby, if you look hard enough.

examples.en: It's fun to climb on a tree.
examples.ja: 木の上に登るのは楽しいです。

examples.en: Do not wear jeans when climbing a mountain.
examples.ja: 山を登るときは、ジーパンをはかないで下さいね。

examples.en: A dream of mine is to climb Mt. Fuji at least once in my lifetime.
examples.ja: 一生の内、少なくとも一度は富士山に登ることが夢なんです。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>climb</kanji> so the verb vocab version would be <vocabulary>to climb</vocabulary> (or <vocabulary>to ascend</vocabulary>), if that's the kind of thing you're into.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. This has the same reading as 上る which you learned all that time ago in Level 1. If you can remember that, you can remember this one!

examples.en: Mountain climbing is fun.
examples.ja: 登山は楽しいです。

examples.en: My favorite part of mountain climbing is eating rice balls on the mountain.
examples.ja: 登山の楽しみは山で食べるおにぎりです。

examples.en: "How about we go mountain climbing?" "Well I don’t know about that."
examples.ja: 「登山に行くってのはどう？」「さあ、どうしようかなあ。」

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Climb</kanji> a <kanji>mountain</kanji>. That is <vocabulary>mountain climbing</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Note this uses the alternative と reading, not to be confused with とう (actually, very confusing, sorry!). Just imagine you cut your <reading>toe</reading> off with an ice pick while mountain climbing. You know it's a short と because your toe is now short. And さん becomes ざん thanks to our old friend rendaku.

examples.en: Maybe I should wear a coat today.
examples.ja: 今日はコートを着た方がいいかも。

examples.en: Have you ever almost gone out of the house without getting dressed?
examples.ja: 服を着ないで家を出そうになったことある？

examples.en: When I'm in a uniform, I feel refreshed.
examples.ja: 制服を着ると気持ちまで引き締まります。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>wear</kanji> so this word means <vocabulary>to wear</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to put on</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: What do you want <vocabulary>to wear</vocabulary> today? How about a dress made entirely of <reading>key</reading>s (き)? Feel the metal on your skin and the weight on your shoulders. It's not a comfortable thing to put on. Maybe just stick with wearing a single key around your neck next time.

examples.en: Isn't that skirt a bit too short?
examples.ja: そのスカート、ちょっと短すぎるんじゃない？

examples.en: The baby's short, flailing arms and legs are so cute!
examples.ja: 赤ちゃんが短い手足をバタバタさせてるのは本当にかわいい。

examples.en: Wah! I didn’t know your tail was shorter than mine.
examples.ja: わぁ！あんたの尻尾が私より短いなんて、知らなかったわ。

meaning_mnemonic:
This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>short</kanji>? It's <vocabulary>short</vocabulary>.

This word is used to describe things that are short in length, not in height, like 短いトンネル (a short tunnel) or 短いスカート (a short skirt). It can also be used for things that are <vocabulary>brief</vocabulary>, like speeches, meetings, or messages.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

Who has <vocabulary>short</vocabulary> hair and always wears shorts? It's <reading>Ms. Ca</reading>rr (みじか)! Everyone always recognizes Ms. Carr because she's the one with the short hair and shorts, no matter the weather. Ms. Carr, the ultimate short style icon!

examples.en: Where did you buy that tanto?
examples.ja: その短刀、どこで買ったの？

examples.en: My brother has a short sword.
examples.ja: 兄は短刀を持っています。

examples.en: A dagger can also be a weapon, so please carry them with caution.
examples.ja: 短刀は武器にもなりえるので注意して所持して下さいね。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>short</kanji> <kanji>sword</kanji> is the <vocabulary>short sword</vocabulary>. What's another word for a short sword? It's a <vocabulary>dagger</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: The short-term experiment is over.
examples.ja: 短期の実験が終わりました。

examples.en: What should I do in order to master hiragana and katakana in a short period of time?
examples.ja: 短期でひらがなとカタカナをマスターにするにはどうしたらいいですか？

examples.en: Maybe I should do a short term part-time job during spring break.
examples.ja: 春休みは短期のアルバイトをしようかな。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>short</kanji> <kanji>period of time</kanji> is the <vocabulary>short term</vocabulary>. You know not to think short term anyways, right? You're learning kanji, after all.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: This is spring water.
examples.ja: これは泉の水です。

examples.en: There is a small spring in this city.
examples.ja: この街には小さな泉があります。

examples.en: Wow! You look beautiful! Did you go on a special diet? Or did you find the Fountain of Youth?
examples.ja: わぁ！すごく綺麗。何か特別なダイエットでもしたの？それとも、若返りの泉でも見つけたとか？

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You're looking at a natural <vocabulary>spring</vocabulary> in the ground. Water is bubbling up, but then something changes. It looks a bit clogged... something is poking out. Then, all of a sudden, Mario flies out of the springs, falls in front of you and yells: "<reading>izumeeeee</reading> (いずみ), Mario!"

examples.en: Red wine goes well with beef.
examples.ja: 牛肉には赤ワインが合います。

examples.en: Is this the right phone number?
examples.ja: この電話番号で合ってますか？

examples.en: Indian cuisine in America is altered quite a bit from how it’s prepared in India to suit American tastes.
examples.ja: アメリカのインド料理は、アメリカ人の口に合うよう、実際のインドでの調理方法とはかなり違った方法で作られている。

meaning_mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>suit</kanji> so the verb version is <vocabulary>to suit</vocabulary>. 

This word also means <vocabulary>to come together</vocabulary> as well. Presumably when something suits something else, it comes together with it flawlessly. That's why this word also has this other meaning (and it will be important for future vocab as well).
reading_mnemonic: You want to find a pet <vocabulary>to suit</vocabulary> your personal style, so you get matched with an <reading>a</reading>ardvark (あ). An aardvark will match the ant mounds you use for chairs and couches, it's the perfect match.

examples.en: Hey mom, when will it be decided what we will eat today?
examples.ja: ねえママ、今日は何を食べるか決まるのはいつ？

examples.en: Has the day of enrollment been decided?
examples.ja: いつが入学の日か決まりました？

examples.en: There are too many roommates and the house rules have yet to be decided.
examples.ja: ルームメイトの数が多すぎて、中々家のルールが決まらない。

meaning_mnemonic: You've hopefully seen the word 決める before. This is similar, except instead of deciding something, something gets decided. Rules are decided, a schedule gets decided — that kind of thing. It's intransitive, so it doesn't take a direct object. So 決まる means to be decided. Verbs ending in okurigana that rhyme with ある tend to be intransitive like this. You can remember this because if something is ある, it's just there, existing, not acting on anything else. That's why verbs that sound like it are often intransitive too!
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as 決める, so make sure you know that word so you can apply that knowledge over here.

examples.en: My father is also a boozer.
examples.ja: 私の父親も酒飲みなんですよ。

examples.en: Koichi likes drinking, but he isn't like an alcoholic.
examples.ja: コウイチはお酒は好きだけど、酒飲みってほどじゃあないですよ。

examples.en: He’s a heavy drinker but he doesn’t like red wine.
examples.ja: 彼は大酒飲みだが、赤ワインが苦手だ。

meaning_mnemonic: We have <kanji>alcohol</kanji> and a variant form of 飲む (to drink). So you know this has to do with drinking alcohol. It means a <vocabulary>boozer</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>drunkard</vocabulary>, someone who drinks a lot of alcohol!
reading_mnemonic: The readings are the vocab words お酒 and 飲む combined together into one. You can guess it's a kun'yomi reading because of the み on the end of 飲, which should make you think back to vocab words that use these kanji and the kun'yomi readings. If you can do that, you can read this word (and many others, probably!).

examples.en: Have you ever heard the sound of a giraffe?
examples.ja: キリンの鳴き声を聞いたことがありますか。

examples.en: I woke up to the sound of birds chirping in the morning.
examples.ja: 朝、鳥の鳴き声で起きた。

examples.en: I hear a puppy barking under the vending machine.
examples.ja: 自動販売機の下から子犬の鳴き声が聞こえるんです。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>chirp</kanji> <kanji>voice</kanji> is a sound an animal makes. Sure, it works for birds (which chirp), but it also works with most other animals as well. So, we call this an <vocabulary>animal cry</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The readings are those that you learned with the kanji. 声 gets changed to ごえ, though, so take note of that in your head. Perhaps you can imagine an animal that does a "GOEEEEE" cry.

examples.en: What's the drink that Koichi's drinking?
examples.ja: コウイチの飲んでいる飲み物は何ですか？

examples.en: Ice cream is not a drink.
examples.ja: アイスクリームは飲み物ではありませんよ。

examples.en: "Would you like something cold to drink?" "Well then, could I have two cartons of milk?"
examples.ja: 「何か冷たい飲み物はいかがですか？」「それでは、牛乳パックを二本頂けますか？」

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>thing</kanji> you <kanji>drink</kanji> is a <vocabulary>beverage</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: These are both the kun'yomi readings. You've learned them already, so you already know how to read this word!

examples.en: If you could hear me, you should've said something!
examples.ja: 聞こえたんだったら、ちゃんと返事してよ！

examples.en: We can hear the sound of the sea.
examples.ja: 海の音が聞こえますね。

examples.en: I understand it sounds harsh, but I’m up to my neck in lame excuses.
examples.ja: きつい言い方に聞こえることは分かってるんだけど、つまらない言い訳はしたくないの。

meaning_mnemonic:
You've seen 聞く by now hopefully. This is similar, but instead of meaning "to hear" it means <vocabulary>to be hearable</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be audible</vocabulary>. To remember this, just think about how you can hear a こえ (voice) coming from the middle of the word 聞こえる. It's audible to you too, right?

聞こえる is used when sounds reach your ears on their own, like "I can hear music from next door." It's more about what comes to your ears, not what you're trying to listen to. That's why it also means <vocabulary>to be able to hear</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from 聞く, so if you know the reading of that word, you can apply it here.

examples.en: If you have a concern, it is best to consult friends or parents.
examples.ja: 心配事があるときは、友人や親に相談するのが一番です。

examples.en: My worries about today's exams are that I didn't study enough yesterday.
examples.ja: 今日の試験の心配事は、昨日の勉強不足です。

examples.en: My biggest worry is volcanic ash falling over the city.
examples.ja: 私の一番の心配事は、町に降り落ちる火山灰です。

meaning_mnemonic: Remember how 心配 means "a worry" and 事 can mean "thing"? Well, if you have a worry over some specific thing, then you probably have some <vocabulary>cares</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>worries</vocabulary>. What are your 心配事 these days?
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the reading of 心配 (which you've hopefully gotten down okay by now) and 事 using the (こと) reading. It is rendaku'd, as well, so beware of the ごと. (Just another 心配事, am I right?)

examples.en: What was the on'yomi for this kanji again?
examples.ja: この漢字の音読みって何だっけ？

examples.en: On'yomi readings are based on how kanji are read in China.
examples.ja: 音読みは中国の漢字読み方がベースです。

examples.en: What’s the difference between the Chinese reading and the Japanese reading in the Japanese language?
examples.ja: 日本語の音読みと訓読みの違いは何ですか？

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>sound</kanji> <kanji>read</kanji>ing. What could this be...? Wait a sec, think to Japanese and kanji. What's the reading that uses sounds from another place, specifically China? That's the <vocabulary>Chinese reading</vocabulary>, aka the <vocabulary>on'yomi</vocabulary>. Sounds familiar?
reading_mnemonic: The reading for 音 is the 音読み. 読み uses the kun'yomi, though, strangely. Way to mess up the one word that should be all on'yomi, Japan. Way. To. Go.

examples.en: That taxi driver is a good-looking guy.
examples.ja: あのタクシーの運転手、イケメンだね。

examples.en: Please rest assured, as we are renting a bus with a driver.
examples.ja: 運転手付きのバスをレンタルしてるので安心して下さい。

examples.en: The driver seemed okay but his car was totaled in the accident.
examples.ja: 運転手は大丈夫だったみたいだけど、車は事故でめちゃくちゃになっていたよ。

meaning_mnemonic: You know that <vocabulary>運転</vocabulary> has to do with driving, right? And you know that <kanji>手</kanji> often has to do with a person doing something in words like these. So, a person who does driving is what? A <vocabulary>driver</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is all on'yomi, because it's jukugo. You should know the on'yomi reading of 手 by now just by seeing similar word patterns to this one.

examples.en: Let's collect fallen leaves and start a fire.
examples.ja: 落ち葉を集めて火を起こそう。

examples.en: I made this greeting card from the fallen leaves.
examples.ja: このグリーティングカード、落ち葉で作ったんだよ。

examples.en: I love the feel and sound when stepping on fallen leaves.
examples.ja: 落ち葉を踏んだ時の感触と音が大好きです。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>leaf</kanji> that <kanji>fall</kanji>s are <vocabulary>fallen leaves</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading for this one is a bit strange. You'll have to pull from your knowledge of 落ちる and use that for the first half. Then, 葉 is rendaku'd to ば. Because, when a leaf falls, Scrooge says "BAH! Humbug!" (probably because he's losing money).

examples.en: Our father always gives us advice.
examples.ja: 父親はいつも私たちに助言をしてくれます。

examples.en: The father of this child is you.
examples.ja: この子の父親は、あなたです。

examples.en: Everyone in my family loves my dad.
examples.ja: うちの家族はみんな父親のことが大好きです。

meaning_mnemonic: Your <kanji>father</kanji> <kanji>parent</kanji> is your <vocabulary>father</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading here is pretty weird. It's all kun'yomi. My guess is this translates literally to "father parent" (two different words, therefore uses the other readings). You should know the readings of these two separate words, though. It is 父 (ちち) and 親 (おや).

examples.en: My mother is always full of energy.
examples.ja: うちの母親はいつも元気です。

examples.en: This cow's mother was sold a long time ago.
examples.ja: この牛の母親は、とっくに売られてしまったんです。

examples.en: How has your life changed now that you have become a mother?
examples.ja: 母親になってみて、人生はどう変わりましたか？

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>mother</kanji> <kanji>parent</kanji> is the <vocabulary>mother</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading for this is strange. It's the kun'yomi vocab reading, probably because the literal translation is "mother parent" and therefore consists of a couple words combined together into one concept. So, make sure you know the separate word readings of 母 and 親. If you do, you should be able to read this too.

examples.en: This is probably my third favorite Beatles's song.
examples.ja: この曲、ビートルズの中で三番目くらいにすき。

examples.en: The third child my mom and dad had was my baby brother.
examples.ja: 母と父の間に三番目に生まれたのが弟です。

examples.en: Did you know that Japan has the third highest number of inhabited islands in the world, after Indonesia and the Philippines?
examples.ja: 日本の有人島の多さは、インドネシア、フィリピンに次いで、世界で三番目だってこと、知ってた？

meaning_mnemonic:
Remember 一番目? This is just like that, but with three, making it <vocabulary>the third thing</vocabulary> or simply <vocabulary>the third</vocabulary>.

Again, think about your eyeball collection. This time, you're showing someone the third eyeball in your display case. It just happens to be third in line, but honestly it's just as beautiful as the two that come before it.
reading_mnemonic: Use your knowledge of the reading for 一番目 to remember the reading for this word as well.

examples.en: The way he talks makes me really annoyed.
examples.ja: 話し方が本当にイライラするのよね。

examples.en: You talk like a Japanese person.
examples.ja: まるで日本人みたいな話し方ですね。

examples.en: I want to learn a persuasive way of talking.
examples.ja: 説得力のある話し方を学びたいです。

meaning_mnemonic: Your <kanji>speak</kanji>ing <kanji>way</kanji> is… your <vocabulary>way of speaking</vocabulary>, or your <vocabulary>speaking style</vocabulary>. This includes your tone of voice, speed, and even how you use gestures when talking. It's more about the whole way you communicate, not just the wording or how you phrase things.
reading_mnemonic: This uses the kun'yomi readings from the vocab words 話す and 方. So as long as you're okay with those, you can apply that knowledge over here.

examples.en: A small boy fell.
examples.ja: 小さい男の子が転んでしまいました。

examples.en: I almost fell on the street because of the snow.
examples.ja: 雪のせいで道で転んでしまいそうでした。

examples.en: Koichi didn't cry when he fell today.
examples.ja: コウイチ、今日は転んでも泣かなかったね。

meaning_mnemonic: Do you remember the word 転がる? This is kind of similar, instead of rolling, this is more for when something falls and hits the ground. It means <vocabulary>to fall over</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to fall down</vocabulary>. Just imagine someone falling off a chair face first into the dirt and making a ぶ sound.
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from 転がる. Hopefully you know that one well enough to associate it with this one, meaning you can read them both.

examples.en: The plan is that all employees will come together on a trip to Kyushu.
examples.ja: 九州への旅行で全社員が集まる予定です。

examples.en: A lot of money was raised through crowdfunding.
examples.ja: クラウドファンディングで、こんなにたくさんのお金が集まりました。

examples.en: Look! A group of miscreants are gathering over there!
examples.ja: 見て！あそこにヤンキーたちがたくさん集まってるよ。

meaning_mnemonic: I bet you remember 集める means "to collect something." But this time you're not collecting something. Instead, something just… collects.
