In other words, 集まる means to come together or to gather. Friends come together, or fans gather at a venue — that sort of thing. No direct object needed, since this is intransitive. Verbs ending in okurigana that rhyme with ある tend to be intransitive like this. You can remember this because if something is ある, it's just there, existing, not acting on anything else. That's why verbs that sound like it are often intransitive too!
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as 集める so if you know that word you'll know how to read this word as well.

examples.en: Oh, you dropped your handkerchief.
examples.ja: あの、ハンカチ落としましたよ。

examples.en: You should immediately stop doing things that will make people lose faith in you.
examples.ja: そんな信用を落とすようなことは今すぐ止めた方がいいよ。

examples.en: Today I bought a book called 'How to Make a Man Fall In Love With You,' but I lost it somewhere on the way back home.
examples.ja: 今日、『男を落とす方法』っていう本を買ったんだけど、帰り道にどこかで落としちゃったみたいなんだよね。

meaning_mnemonic: You've seen how 落ちる means "to fall down." Now you're doing the action of "falling something down," aka you're dropping it. You can remember this because you kind of <reading>toss</reading> (とす) something and it drops to the ground, making this word mean <vocabulary>to drop something</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from 落ちる. So long as you know that word you can apply that reading over here, too.

examples.en: This is the end.
examples.ja: これで終わりだ。

examples.en: "All is well that ends well," right?
examples.ja: 「終わり良ければ全て良し」でしょ？

examples.en: Work ends this week and Christmas holidays starts next week! Aww I can't wait for that.
examples.ja: 今週で仕事も終わりで、来週からはクリスマス休暇だー！あー、待ちきれない。

meaning_mnemonic: By now you should know that 終わる means "to end" or "to finish." So what is this noun-version of that word? It would be <vocabulary>the end</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>the finish</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from 終わる. So long as you know that word, you can learn this word's reading as well!

examples.en: What time was the last train?
examples.ja: 終電、何時だっけ？

examples.en: I'll get going as the last train of the JR Line is coming soon.
examples.ja: もうすぐJRの終電だから、行くね。

examples.en: When I miss the last train and take a taxi, it costs about 5000 yen to get home.
examples.ja: 終電を逃してタクシーに乗ると、大体家まで五千円かかります。

meaning_mnemonic: We've seen a few times where 電 refers to a train. They're big deals, after all, and use a ton of electricity. So, the <kanji>end</kanji> train for this word would refer to the <vocabulary>last train</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: What time does this shop open?
examples.ja: このお店は何時に開きますか。

examples.en: The venue hasn't opened yet, so let's go get a beer for the time being.
examples.ja: 会場はまだ開かないから、とりあえずビールを買いに行こう。

examples.en: Um... Your fly is open.
examples.ja: あの... 社会の窓が開いていますよ。

meaning_mnemonic: You should know 開ける by now. This word is similar to that, except it has to do with when things are just open. It's the same thing, though. The meaning is also <vocabulary>to open</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
Do you remember the reading for 開ける, which you learned in level 10? That's right, it's あける! So if you know the reading of that word (I hope you do!) then you can apply that knowledge here.

Just a quick side note — 開く can also be read as ひらく, but we're going to focus on the あく reading here. Since ひらく has slightly different meanings, we won't accept it as a reading for this word, so be sure to enter あく!

examples.en: I never expected something like this would happen.
examples.ja: まさかこんなことが起こるなんて、思ってもみなかったよ。

examples.en: Please try thinking through why something like this happened.
examples.ja: どうしてこんなことが起こったのか、よく考えてみてください。

examples.en: It was a huge earthquake, the kind that occurs only once every few hundred years.
examples.ja: それは数百年に一度起こるか起こらないかの大地震でした。

meaning_mnemonic: You know that 起きる means "to wake up", but did you learn its secondary meaning, "to occur"? Well, this word means only <vocabulary>to occur</vocabulary>. Just imagine an incident occurring involving a uranium <reading>core</reading> (こる) to remember that this means <vocabulary>to occur</vocabulary>. After all, uranium core incidents don't wake up, do they?
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji and the same as 起きる too, meaning you should be able to put together the reading on your own.

examples.en: My father is always worried about his brother.
examples.ja: 父は兄のことをいつも心配しています。

examples.en: The staff are worried as the president has not yet come to work, although it's already past eleven o'clock.
examples.ja: 社長が十一時になっても出社してないので社員たちは心配しています。

examples.en: If you have time to worry about sales, make more sales calls!
examples.ja: 売り上げを心配する時間があるならセールスの電話を一本でも多くしてよ！

meaning_mnemonic: You know that 心配 is "a worry." What about the verb version of that? It would be <vocabulary>to worry</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes straight from 心配 so try to make sure you know that word so you can read this word! It's also all jukugo on'yomi reading, too, so you should be able to figure it out regardless.

examples.en: My stomach growled.
examples.ja: お腹が鳴ってしまった。

examples.en: The phone is ringing.
examples.ja: 電話が鳴っている。

examples.en: The door bell rang.
examples.ja: ドアのベルが鳴った。

meaning_mnemonic: You learned 鳴く means "to chirp" (or some other animal sound). 鳴る is similar, but it's used when something just makes a sound, like a phone ringing, a bell jingling, or thunder rumbling. So 鳴る means <vocabulary>to sound</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to ring</vocabulary>. You know this because 鳴る can also be used for when your stomach rumbles: "<reading>rrrr</reading>" (る)!
reading_mnemonic: The reading can come from 鳴く. So long as you know the reading for that word you can know the reading for this word as well.

examples.en: My mother sings in the shower every day.
examples.ja: 母は毎日シャワー中に歌う。

examples.en: I don't like singing in front of people.
examples.ja: 人前で歌うのは好きじゃないんです。

examples.en: I'm going to make dinner today, so could you sing for me?
examples.ja: 今日は僕が夕食を作るから、君は僕のために歌ってよ。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. One of the kanji's meanings is <kanji>sing</kanji> so the verb vocab version of this is <vocabulary>to sing</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: Awesomely, this uses the same reading as the reading for the vocab words 歌. Just throw the う onto the end and you have yourself the reading. So, sing your heart out and learn this word easily. "IIIIiiIIIiiiII WILLL ALLllwaYYYs Loovvve YoOooOOooooOOOO ♬!"

examples.en: You are so selfish!
examples.ja: ほんと、勝手だよね！

examples.en: Don't say whatever you want.
examples.ja: 勝手なことばっかり言わないでよ！

examples.en: Could you stop opening the fridge or eating chips at someone else's house without permission?
examples.ja: 他人の家で勝手に冷蔵庫を開けたりポテチを食べるの、やめてくれる？。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>hand</kanji> (or person, as you know 手 often refers to a person) that <kanji>win</kanji>s gets to do <vocabulary>as one pleases</vocabulary> without regard for anyone else.
reading_mnemonic: The reading for this is weird. It's all kun'yomi, which luckily you've seen before, but still strange. I guess when you do <vocabulary>as one pleases</vocabulary> you can read kanji however you want, in this case the kun'yomi readings. Do note that there's a small っ in there before 手, presumably to connect the two readings of the two kanji together.

examples.en: This letter conveyed my mother's feelings.
examples.ja: この手紙で母の気持ちは伝わりました。

examples.en: Apparently not all teammates got the message that there won't be practice tomorrow.
examples.ja: 明日が休みなの、チームメイト全員に伝わってなかったみたい。

examples.en: Even though you can't speak Japanese well, if you try to speak with your heart, people will understand.
examples.ja: 日本語が上手に話せなくても心で話せばきっと相手に伝わりますよ。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji means transmit, and this verb version is to be transmitted or to be conveyed. It's intransitive, so it doesn't take a direct object. A message is transmitted, or your feelings are conveyed — that kind of thing. Verbs ending in okurigana that rhyme with ある tend to be intransitive like this. You can remember this because if something is ある, it's just there, existing, not acting on anything else. That's why verbs that sound like it are often intransitive too!
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading.

Lucky for you, the kanji readings for transitive and intransitive verbs are almost always the same. Once you learn one, you know them both! This reading is the same as 伝える.

examples.en: That day is not convenient for me, could you cancel it?
examples.ja: その日は都合が悪くて、キャンセルしてもらってもいいですか？

examples.en: If it works for you, why don't we go to the bookstore together?
examples.ja: もし都合が良ければ、一緒に本屋に行きませんか？

examples.en: "Which day is convenient for you, Saturday or Sunday?" "It makes no difference to me."
examples.ja: 「土曜日と日曜日、どちらの方が都合がいい？」「どちらでもいいよ。」

meaning_mnemonic:
This one makes no sense (sorry!). When you <kanji>join</kanji> together with someone at a <kanji>metropolis</kanji>, you do it <vocabulary>at your convenience</vocabulary>. You're important, after all, so you just do what you want and make the other person wait in this giant metropolis while you move along leisurely. Imagine this, and keep thinking "at your convenience" as you walk about.

This word is usually used in a nicer way, though. As in, "do it at your convenience!"
reading_mnemonic:
The reading for 都 is an exception from what you learned with the kanji. To remember this, just think about someone who does something at their own convenience. They say, I'm going <reading>to go</reading> (つごう) where I want, when I want, at my own convenience.

The 合 (ごう) part is a reading you know from the kanji, though, so if you can get to "to go" with the mnemonic, you should be able to put two and two together to know that it's a long vowel ごう.

examples.en: Could you project the slides onto the screen for me?
examples.ja: スクリーンにスライドを映してもらえますか？

examples.en: I think others are like mirrors that reflect ourselves.
examples.ja: 他人は自分を映すかがみだと思うんです。

examples.en: Why don't we use this white wall as a screen to project the movie?
examples.ja: この白いカベをスクリーン代わりにして映画を映すのはどうでしょう。

examples.en: What's the intention behind showing a close-up of a bagel at this point in this movie?
examples.ja: この映画、ここでベーグルをアップ映す意図は何なの？

meaning_mnemonic: You know that 映る is "to be reflected." Now you're doing the reflecting, which is really projecting (light). That's why this word is <vocabulary>to project</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as 映る. So long as you know the reading of 映る you should be able to read this one too.

examples.en: The man demanded money.
examples.ja: 男は金を要求した。

examples.en: Employees are demanding time off.
examples.ja: 社員が休みを要求しています。

examples.en: Customers are demanding fast responses.
examples.ja: 顧客は速い対応を要求しています。

meaning_mnemonic: You hopefully remember that 要求 means "demand" . When you make that a verb, it becomes <vocabulary>to demand something</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is just the vocab word 要求. It's also the regular on'yomi jukugo reading.

examples.en: Yogurt helps you digest food.
examples.ja: ヨーグルトは食べ物の消化を助けてくれます。

examples.en: Koichi's having a touch of diarrhea, so please have him eat something easy to digest.
examples.ja: コウイチは下り気味だから、消化の良いものを食べさせてあげてね。

examples.en: I haven’t finished digesting the ramen I ate for lunch.
examples.ja: 昼に食べたラーメンをまだ消化しきっていない。

meaning_mnemonic: What is something that will first <kanji>extinguish</kanji> something and then <kanji>change</kanji> it? One thing I can think of is your body. It takes in food, extinguishes it in your stomach, then changes it into things your body can use (and then excrete). That's why this "extinguish-change" process is your <vocabulary>digestion</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: It seems like I am lucky today. I won a lottery.
examples.ja: 今日が運が良いみたいで宝くじが当たったんだ。

examples.en: What matters for gambling is your luck, rather than your ability.
examples.ja: ギャンブルは実力よりも運が大切だ。

examples.en: I might have run out of luck though, and I don't want to use it up on something like this.
examples.ja: こんなことで使い果たしたくはないけど、これで運を使い果たしちゃったかも。

meaning_mnemonic: This takes the <kanji>luck</kanji> meaning from the kanji. Think of it this way: If you're "carrying" you're going to create your own luck. Now nobody will mess with you, kanji gangstah. You carry guns and have a ton of <vocabulary>luck</vocabulary> because of it.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji! How... shall I say... <vocabulary>luck</vocabulary>-filled?

examples.en: A button came off.
examples.ja: ボタンが取れちゃった。

examples.en: It might be difficult for this stain to be removed.
examples.ja: このシミは取れないかもしれないね。

examples.en: Renting an office in the business district will be considerably expensive, but it’s important for our image and I think it will pay for itself in about a year.
examples.ja: ビジネス街にオフィスを設けるとなると賃料はかなり高くつきますが、我々のイメージにとって重要な事でもありますし、一年ぐらいで元は取れるのではないかと思うんです。

meaning_mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.

This is an intransitive verb. That means it does not take a direct object. Something comes off. Something is removed. No direct object here. That's why this verb means <vocabulary>to come off</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be removed</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading.

Lucky for you, the kanji readings for transitive and intransitive verbs are almost always the same. Once you learn one, you know them both! This reading is the same as 取る.

examples.en: The temperature fell suddenly.
examples.ja: 気温が急に下がった。

examples.en: Today's highest temperature will be 40 degrees.
examples.ja: 今日の最高気温は四十度です。

examples.en: The temperature difference between the morning and night is intense.
examples.ja: 朝と夜の気温の差が激しいんです。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>energy</kanji> of the <kanji>warm</kanji>th will cause the <vocabulary>temperature</vocabulary> to go up and down. Energy goes up? Higher temperature because of more movement and activity. Energy goes down? Well, temperature gets colder and slower.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: He is Tom.
examples.ja: 彼がトムさんです。

examples.en: He drinks coffee every day.
examples.ja: 彼は毎日コーヒーを飲みます。

examples.en: Today is a home date with my boyfriend♡
examples.ja: 今日は彼とおうちデート♡

examples.en: Shit! I just broke the stupid teapot. He would get so upset if he knew.
examples.ja: しまった！急須を壊しちゃった。彼が知ったらめちゃくちゃ怒るだろうな。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

examples.en: They are all Canadians.
examples.ja: 彼らはみんな、カナダ人なんですよ。

examples.en: I am about to go play hockey with those guys.
examples.ja: これから、彼らとホッケーをしに行くところなんです。

examples.en: I met them at a maple farm.
examples.ja: 彼らとは、メープルファームで出会いました。

examples.en: Those guys are good friends.
examples.ja: 彼らは仲の良い友達です。

meaning_mnemonic: This is <kanji>he</kanji> but plural. The "ra" makes it plural, making it "<vocabulary>they</vocabulary>" or "<vocabulary>them</vocabulary>." In modern Japanese, this word generally refers to a group of men or boys, but it can also be used for mixed groups as well.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

examples.en: "Oh, there's someone over there." "Uh, there’s no one there…?"
examples.ja: 「あ、あそこに誰かいる。」「え、誰もいないよ？」

examples.en: Let's ask someone!
examples.ja: 誰かに聞いてみよう！

examples.en: Someone on the team will play rock Rock-Paper-Scissors with the other party as a representative.
examples.ja: チームの誰かが代表として相手とじゃんけんします。

meaning_mnemonic: 誰 is <kanji>who</kanji>, 誰か is like asking "who?" If you don't know who it is, you just know it's <vocabulary>someone</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from the reading you learned with the kanji.

examples.en: I have a lot of accumulated fatigue because of stress from work.
examples.ja: 仕事のストレスのせいで疲労がたまっているんです。

examples.en: These shoes are great! I even walked all day at Disneyland and was shocked that my feet didn't get fatigued.
examples.ja: このクツ、すごくいいよ！ディズニーランドで一日歩いたのに、足に疲労が出なくてビビったぐらい。

examples.en: If you drink this energy drink, you can get rid of fatigue right away.
examples.ja: このエナジードリンクを飲めば疲労が一発でとれるんです。

meaning_mnemonic:
You're <kanji>tired</kanji> from <kanji>labor</kanji>. From this, you're showing <vocabulary>fatigue</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>weariness</vocabulary>.

疲労 is a little formal, so you might encounter it more often in writing than in conversation.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: "Which floor?" "Fourth please." "This elevator doesn't stop on the fourth floor."
examples.ja: 「何階ですか？」「四階をおねがいします。」「このエレベーターは四階には止まりませんよ。」

examples.en: There's no wonder, but the view from the sixty-fifth floor is splendid.
examples.ja: さすが六十五階からのビューは見事ですね。

examples.en: My friend lives in a tower apartment with thirty floors.
examples.ja: 友人が三十階建てのタワーマンションに住んでいます。

meaning_mnemonic:
You know that the kanji refers to a <kanji>floor</kanji> (as in the "fifth floor"). This word represents the version that comes after a number, shown with a 〜. Essentially, this has the same meaning as the kanji you learned, making it nice and easy.

Note that floor-counting systems can vary across different countries. In Japan the ground floor is generally called 一階, with the floors above being 二階, 三階, and so on.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Don't type in the 〜 or you'll get it wrong!

examples.en: A lot of people live in the city.
examples.ja: 都市にはたくさんの人が住んでいます。

examples.en: How about living in a lively city area?
examples.ja: 活気のある都市エリアでの生活はどうですか？

examples.en: Do you know any interesting urban legends?
examples.ja: 何かおもしろい都市伝説を知っていますか？

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>metropolis</kanji> <kanji>city</kanji> is a <vocabulary>city</vocabulary>. When you're referring to just a plain ol' city, sans name, you can use this word.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Can you teach me the meaning of this word?
examples.ja: この言葉の意味を教えて下さい。

examples.en: It's hard to put into words, but Koichi is a very special person to me.
examples.ja: うまく言葉にできないけど、コウイチは私にとってすごく特別な人なの。

examples.en: I was at a loss for words.
examples.ja: 私は言葉に詰まった。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>leaf</kanji> of the things you <kanji>say</kanji> is like a leaf from a tree of speaking. That leaf is a part of the whole language, it is a single <vocabulary>word</vocabulary>, though it can add up to be a <vocabulary>language</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>manner of speech</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
The reading for 言 is one you haven't learned, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Now imagine that there are <vocabulary>word</vocabulary>s all over your <reading>coat</reading> (こと). It's completely covered in words. Which <vocabulary>language</vocabulary> are these words in? Why Japanese, of course! Think about which Japanese words you would want written on your coat.

examples.en: Leave it to me.
examples.ja: 僕に任せろ。

examples.en: My younger brother is an elementary school student.
examples.ja: 僕の弟は小学生です。

examples.en: Come with me.
examples.ja: 僕と一緒に行きましょう。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well!
reading_mnemonic: This word uses the same reading as the one you learned with the kanji. <vocabulary> I</vocabulary> certainly like that and I bet you do too.

examples.en: The earth is beautifully blue.
examples.ja: 地球は美しい青色をしています。

examples.en: Where did Koichi go? I think he's somewhere on earth though...
examples.ja: コウイチは一体どこへ行ったのかな？地球の上にはいると思うんだけど...。

examples.en: It is important to protect the environment of the earth.
examples.ja: 地球の環境を守ることは重要です。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>earth</kanji> <kanji>sphere</kanji>! It's where we live and the planet we call home. It's <vocabulary>the earth</vocabulary>!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: First of all, why don't you become a member of the library?
examples.ja: まずは図書館の会員になったらどうですか？

examples.en: Mr. Tanaka is a member of a gym.
examples.ja: 田中さんはスポーツジムの会員です。

examples.en: Do you have a membership card?
examples.ja: 会員カードはお持ちですか。

meaning_mnemonic: If you <kanji>meet</kanji> enough <kanji>member</kanji>s you will become a <vocabulary>member</vocabulary> yourself!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I used to be a sailor on this ship.
examples.ja: 私は昔この船の船員でした。

examples.en: To become a seaman, you have to take various tests.
examples.ja: 船員になるには色々なテストを受けなければいけません。

examples.en: The sailor's work is hard, but the salary is pretty good.
examples.ja: 船員の仕事って大変だけど、お給料は結構良いのよね。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>member</kanji> of a <kanji>boat</kanji> is called a <vocabulary>sailor</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: There are no rice fields in the city.
examples.ja: 都会に田んぼはありませんよ。

examples.en: This is why I don't like city-bred people.
examples.ja: これだから都会育ちはきらいなんだよ！

examples.en: I want to work in the city, not in the countryside like this.
examples.ja: こんな田舎じゃなく、私は都会で働きたいのよ。

meaning_mnemonic: When <kanji>metropolis</kanji>es <kanji>meet</kanji> they become an <vocabulary>urban area</vocabulary>. This word is often used to mean <vocabulary>city</vocabulary> as opposed to the country or rural areas.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: A beautiful blue sky is spreading over the island.
examples.ja: 島には美しい青空が広がっている。

examples.en: Cathy is the most beautiful person on this island.
examples.ja: キャシーは、この島で一番の美人です。

examples.en: I’m going to have you live on this island for a week.
examples.ja: この島で一週間生活をしてもらいます。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

examples.en: I like a story with a conclusion.
examples.ja: 落ちのある話が好きなんです。

examples.en: That was the outcome, huh?
examples.ja: そういう落ちだったのね。

examples.en: His speech didn't have much of a conclusion.
examples.ja: あいつの話には落ちが無いんだよな。

meaning_mnemonic: When you're talking or writing a paper, the part that <kanji>falls</kanji> at the end is the <vocabulary>conclusion</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!

examples.en: The rental period is ten days.
examples.ja: レンタル期間は十日間です。

examples.en: This week is the test period.
examples.ja: 今週はテスト期間中です。

examples.en: This pair of jeans is cheap for a limited time now.
examples.ja: このジーンズ、今なら期間限定で安いですよ。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>period of time</kanji> <kanji>interval</kanji> is still a <vocabulary>period</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>interval</vocabulary> of time.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: He does the same action at the same time every day.
examples.ja: 彼は毎日同じ時間に同じ行動をします。

examples.en: Koichi's behavioral patterns are always the same.
examples.ja: いつもコウイチの行動パターンは決まっている。

examples.en: That person's words and actions don't match up.
examples.ja: あの人は発言と行動が一致していない。

meaning_mnemonic: When you <kanji>go</kanji> to <kanji>move</kanji> you're actually making an <vocabulary>action</vocabulary>. This word can also mean <vocabulary>behavior</vocabulary>, since your actions are what make up your behavior.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: There’s a get-together with people from the lab today.
examples.ja: 今日は研究室の集まりがある。

examples.en: Not many people showed up at today's party and it was also very disorganized.
examples.ja: なんか今日のパーティー、集まりも悪かったし、グダグダだったね。

examples.en: My younger brother brought his girlfriend to our New Year's gathering.
examples.ja: 正月の集まりに弟がガールフレンドを連れてきやがった。

meaning_mnemonic: This is the noun version of the kanji <kanji>gather</kanji>, so it means <vocabulary>gathering</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!

examples.en: Mom planted apple trees in the garden.
examples.ja: ママは庭にリンゴの木を植えました。

examples.en: The residents of the town like planting various kinds of flowers.
examples.ja: 町の住人たちは色々な花を植えるのが好きです。

examples.en: Where do you plan on planting that seed?
examples.ja: この種をどこに植えるつもりだい。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>plant</kanji>, so the verb version is <vocabulary>to plant something</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to grow something</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
You haven't learned this reading for 植 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You decided <vocabulary>to plant</vocabulary> an <reading>u</reading>ni (う) tree in your backyard. That's right, you can plant sea urchins and they'll grow like fruit off a really spiky tree. Just picture it. And then you'll get to eat all the uni you want!

examples.en: I walked by a yakuza kingpin in the underpass.
examples.ja: 地下道でヤクザの親分とすれちがったんだ。

examples.en: Between Tom and Jerry, which is the boss and which is the henchman?
examples.ja: トムとジェリーは、どちらが親分でどちらが子分ですか。

examples.en: The chief will chew us out if we let it slip.
examples.ja: 親分にバレたら大目玉を食らうぞ。

meaning_mnemonic:
Who plays a <kanji>parent</kanji> <kanji>part</kanji> to you? Your <vocabulary>boss</vocabulary> or your <vocabulary>leader</vocabulary>!

親分 is an informal and sort of old-fashioned word for someone who's in charge of close-knit groups, like in gangs or traditional trades such as carpentry and fishing. The 親分 is like a parent figure who takes care of the other members.
reading_mnemonic: This word consists of the kun'yomi reading for 親 and the on'yomi reading for 分. You've learned both of these so you should be able to read this already!

examples.en: Please express your current feelings with kaomoji.
examples.ja: 今の気持ちを顔文字で表してください。

examples.en: This email is written all in kaomoji.
examples.ja: このメール、全部顔文字で書かれてるね。

examples.en: Don’t use kaomoji when you’re emailing a superior!
examples.ja: 上司へのメールに顔文字を使うんじゃない！

meaning_mnemonic: Remember how you learned that 文字 can mean "characters?" Well make a <kanji>face</kanji> out of those characters and you've made a <vocabulary>kaomoji</vocabulary>! ʅ(◔౪◔ ) ʃ
reading_mnemonic: This word consists of the kun'yomi reading for 顔 added to the jukugo word 文字 that you already learned. You've learned these readings before, so reading this word should be nice and easy!

examples.en: There are many CDs in the media club room.
examples.ja: メディア部の部室には、たくさんのCDがあります。

examples.en: Is this the baseball club room? I can tell by the odor.
examples.ja: ここは野球部の部室ですか？ニオイで分かりますよ。

examples.en: First, go get changed into a uniform in the clubroom.
examples.ja: まずは部室でユニフォームに着替えて来て。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>club</kanji> <kanji>room</kanji> is a <vocabulary>clubroom</vocabulary>!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: This library is popular with graduate students.
examples.ja: この図書館は大学院生に人気です。

examples.en: The main activities of graduate students is research.
examples.ja: 大学院生の主な活動は研究です。

examples.en: Apparently, graduate students are quite popular in group dates.
examples.ja: 大学院生は合コンで結構モテるらしいよ。

meaning_mnemonic: Remember how you learned that 大学院 means "graduate school" and 大学生 means "college student?" Well smush them together and you have a  <vocabulary>graduate student</vocabulary>!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: There is a harbor in this town, and there are train lines running through it.
examples.ja: この町には港もあるし、電車も通ってます。

examples.en: Don't approach the port when a typhoon comes.
examples.ja: 台風が来たら、港には近づかないで下さい。

examples.en: There was a mysterious ship drifting in the harbor.
examples.ja: 不思議な船が港に漂着した。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a single kanji with no okurigana, so it's using the kun'yomi reading. You don't know this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You go down to the <vocabulary>harbor</vocabulary> and speak the secret password <reading>me natto</reading> (みなと) to buy some fresh natto. Imagine the salty air hitting your face as you whisper, "me natto." Now eat that yummy natto by the water! Mmmm!

examples.en: Drinking hot water will warm your body.
examples.ja: お湯を飲むと、体が温かくなります。

examples.en: It looks like the mascara doesn't come off with hot water.
examples.ja: そのマスカラはお湯じゃ落ちなさそうだね。

examples.en: Could you boil some water?
examples.ja: お湯を沸かしてくれないか？

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

examples.en: My girlfriend is an active cosplayer on weekends.
examples.ja: 私のガールフレンドは、週末はコスプレイヤーとして活動しています。

examples.en: This volcano has been active for many years now.
examples.ja: この火山はもう何年も活動しています。

examples.en: Action verbs are one of the four verb types categorized from the aspect perspective.
examples.ja: 活動動詞とは動詞を相の観点から四つに分けた内の一つです。

meaning_mnemonic:
The <kanji>lively</kanji> <kanji>move</kanji>s you make are your <vocabulary>activity</vocabulary>.

活動 includes all kinds of activities, including nature activities, club activities, economic activity, and so on!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Today is a national holiday, so the coffee shop I usually go to was closed.
examples.ja: 今日は祭日だからいつものカフェがお休みだったよ。

examples.en: Do you have to work even though it's a national holiday?
examples.ja: 祭日なのに、仕事なの？

examples.en: I forgot it was a holiday and I came to the office.
examples.ja: 祭日だってことを忘れていて、会社に来てしまった。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>festival</kanji> <kanji>day</kanji> is obviously a <vocabulary>festival day</vocabulary>. This word technically refers to days for Shinto festivals or rituals, but sometimes people also use it to mean a general <vocabulary>national holiday</vocabulary>. This is because some of the Japanese national holidays are based on those traditional Shinto festival days!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: That office worker always got tasks done steadily.
examples.ja: その会社員は、いつも着々と仕事をこなしていた。

examples.en: It seems like you're making steady progress on the project.
examples.ja: プロジェクトは着々進んでいるようだね。

examples.en: The project is steadily progressing and is expected to be completed at the end of March.
examples.ja: そのプロジェクトは着々と進行しており、予定通りに三月末に完了する見込みです。

meaning_mnemonic: Something you <kanji>wear</kanji>, and <kanji>wear</kanji> again, is something you <vocabulary>steadily</vocabulary> wear. You do it so often, it's reliable. Also, if you wear something this much it's steadily wearing away too.
reading_mnemonic: This word uses on'yomi readings of the kanji you learned, twice. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Don't hurt me anymore!
examples.ja: これ以上、私を苦しめないで！

examples.en: The rice shortage is tormenting all citizens of Japan.
examples.ja: 米不足が全日本の国民を苦しめている。

examples.en: Without realizing it, I was harassing the first-graders every day.
examples.ja: 知らないうちに、毎日一年生を苦しめていた。

meaning_mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. 

The kanji itself means <kanji>suffer</kanji>, and the verb is all about when you make someone else suffer. That's why it's <vocabulary>to hurt someone</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to torment</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to harass</vocabulary>.

You need to differentiate this from 苦しむ, which is about when YOU suffer. You can remember that 苦しめる is about making someone else suffer with this mnemonic: Who made you suffer? <reading>She ma</reading>de (しめ) me suffer! She's so mean!
reading_mnemonic: By now, you've learned 苦しい and 苦しむ. The kanji in these words all use the same reading! Yay!

examples.en: I want to finish work and leave the office by five.
examples.ja: 五時には仕事を終えて会社を出たい。

examples.en: As soon as the princess finished the cake, she had some tea.
examples.ja: 王女はケーキを食べ終えるとすぐに、お茶を飲んだ。

examples.en: Most fish spend their entire life in water.
examples.ja: ほとんどの魚は水中で一生を終える。

meaning_mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>finish</kanji>, so the verb version is <vocabulary>to finish something</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to end something</vocabulary>.

This is a transitive verb, meaning you finish something, like a long day at work!

You need to differentiate this from 終わる, which is when something just ends on its own. 終える is about when you make something end. Remember it like this: Canadians always end their sentences with "eh" え, right? Well that's how you know they're ending their sentence. Just listen for the "eh," eh?
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading, which you didn't learn with the kanji. Here's a mnemonic to help you:

You finally finished your school project. <reading>"Oh, A!"</reading> (おえ) you say to yourself, as though you can grade your own project.

examples.en: Alright, let's take a look at the answers.
examples.ja: では、解答を見てみましょう。

examples.en: You have five minutes to answer!
examples.ja: 解答時間は５分です！

examples.en: I will now hand out the answer sheets.
examples.ja: それでは解答用紙をくばります。

meaning_mnemonic:
You <kanji>solve</kanji> a problem by working toward the <kanji>answer</kanji>. This is the act of <vocabulary>solving</vocabulary>, which eventually leads to the final <vocabulary>answer</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>solution</vocabulary>!

解答 specifically refers to solving problems and giving answers with a correct solution, often for structured contexts like exams or math problems. It can also refer to the answer or solution itself.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You learned the on'yomi for 答 with 回答, but here's a mnemonic for it in case you forgot:

The reward for <vocabulary>solving</vocabulary> this problem correctly is… A free trip to <reading>とう</reading>きょう! That's right, if you can work out the correct <vocabulary>solution</vocabulary> to this problem, you and a loved one will get an all-expenses-paid trip to とうきょう. Pretty cool, huh?

examples.en: I've already seen that anime.
examples.ja: そのアニメ、もう見たよ。

examples.en: I'm almost done!
examples.ja: もうそろそろ終わる！

examples.en: I understand. I won't come here anymore.
examples.ja: 分かった。ここにはもう来ないね。

meaning_mnemonic:
You've <reading>mow</reading>ed your lawn (もう) <vocabulary>already</vocabulary>? Wow, you're ahead on your mowing. Good work. You'll have to do it again <vocabulary>soon</vocabulary>, though.

This can also mean <vocabulary>yet</vocabulary> in a question, and <vocabulary>anymore</vocabulary> with a negative.

examples.en: I started taking swimming lessons.
examples.ja: 水泳教室に通い始めました。

examples.en: Swimming is an excellent full-body workout.
examples.ja: 水泳はとても良い全身運動です。

examples.en: Swimming classes at school are fun.
examples.ja: 水泳の授業は学校で楽しいです。

meaning_mnemonic:
When you're doing a <kanji>water</kanji> <kanji>swim</kanji>, you're really just… well, <vocabulary>swimming</vocabulary>.

Note that 水泳 will usually refer to swimming as a sport or organized activity. When talking about swimming as a general action, 泳ぎ and 泳ぐ are more commonly used.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You've learned this reading for 水, but not for 泳, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

The only way you can <vocabulary>swim</vocabulary> is by chasing after <reading>a</reading>corns (えい). If somebody isn't dangling an acorn on a stick right in front of your face, you'd never get the motivation to swim. Good thing you're this into acorns.

examples.en: The Atlantic Ocean is very big.
examples.ja: 大西洋はとても大きいです。

examples.en: I have not seen the Atlantic Ocean yet.
examples.ja: 私はまだ大西洋を見たことがありません。

examples.en: The Atlantic Ocean is between America and Europe.
examples.ja: 大西洋はアメリカとヨーロッパの間にあります。

examples.en: I tried to swim across the Atlantic, but gave up after a minute.
examples.ja: 大西洋を泳いでわたろうとしましたが、1分であきらめました。

meaning_mnemonic:
A <kanji>big</kanji> <kanji>west</kanji> <kanji>ocean</kanji>, you say? It's gotta be the <vocabulary>Atlantic Ocean</vocabulary>.

If you think about it from Japan's perspective, the Atlantic is a big, faraway ocean to the west, right?
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses on'yomi readings for all three kanji. You've seen these readings before, but the 西 reading (せい) is still pretty new, so here's a mnemonic refresher just in case:

While swimming in the <vocabulary>Atlantic Ocean</vocabulary>, you find a <reading>sa</reading>ber (せい). Yikes, how'd this rusty old saber get here? This thing must have floated across the Atlantic from some seaside battlefield of yore. Those old sabers are always washing up on Atlantic shores, you know.
